title: Is it possible for a high functioning autistic person to get all the help they can get and barely show any symptoms of autism? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Autism is a spectrum condition. Everyone is affected differently. We all struggle in some area or another, but some of us struggle more than others. One reason for this is that some of us are more capable of masking than others so our autism looks less intense to others. However, we are having to work extremely hard to mask and it is exhausting for us. Just because it appears less problematic to others, does not mean it is easier for us. Another reason is that we are highly sensitive and tend to have specific needs that others might not because of this increased sensitivity. This means we may require very precise environments to thrive in. If we are exposed to the right environments, we're less likely to feel sensory discomfort that contributes to some of the outward behaviours of autism. So we have to be careful when talking about ‘high functioning’ autism, because it can be very demoralising for the person and dismiss the effort required to be able to function at that level. ‘High functioning’ can be more disabled than what people might think, just as ‘low functioning’ are more capable than what people might think. We're very quick to make assumptions as humans. Autism itself relates to how the brain processes information differently from the majority. The outward behaviours are just expressions and coping mechanisms. We use these behaviours to measure and diagnose autism, but they are in fact separate from autism. We can mask how we respond to a particular neurological function, but we cannot mask the function itself and nobody else can see that function because we cannot climb inside another person's brain.
